content.text: State the name of a measuring device for timing the oscillations
State a reason why the student measures the time for ten oscillations, rather than for one
One of the results is incorrect. On the table, draw a ring around the incorrect result.
Calculate the average value for the time for ten complete oscillations
average time = .........\(s\)
Determine the time for one complete oscillation. State your answer to two significant figures
The student repeats the procedure. His results are shown in the table
A student clamps a metre rule to the end of a bench, as shown in Fig. 1.1. He attaches a mass to the end of the rule
The student displaces the end of the rule by a small distance. The rule oscillates up and down. The student measures the time for ten complete oscillations
The students plan to drop a stick into the middle of the river from bridge X. The stick moves with the water between bridge X and bridge Y
Describe how the students can determine the average speed of the stick
The stick moves with constant speed
One statement correctly describes the horizontal forces acting on the stick
Put a tick \((\checkmark)\) in the box next to the correct statement
Only a forward force acts
The forward force and the backward force are equal
The forward force is greater than the backward force
The backward force is greater than the forward force
Fig. 2.1 shows a river flowing through a village. There are two bridges across the river
Two students plan to measure the speed of a stick as it floats on the river between bridge X and bridge Y
Fig. 3.2 shows the forces acting on the marker at one moment in time
Calculate the resultant force on the marker
resultant force = .........N
direction =
Fig. 3.3 shows part of the metal chain. It is made from small metal loops
A damaged loop is removed from the chain. Describe a method to determine the density of the metal from which the loops are made
Fig 3.1 shows a warning marker floating on the surface of a lake
The marker is attached by a metal chain to a heavy object on the bottom of the lake
Name the energy source for each method
In Fig. 4.1a, the energy source is
In Fig. 4.1b, the energy source is
State two advantages of using renewable sources for generating electricity compared to using a coal-fired power station
State one disadvantage of using renewable sources for generating electricity compared to using a coal-fired power station
Fig. 4.1 shows two methods for generating electricity using renewable sources
The atoms are usually arranged in regular patterns in a
The state of matter with the lowest density is a
Evaporation takes place when the most energetic molecules leave the surface of a
A small force can change the volume of a
Complete the sentences. Choose from the words in the box
The words may be used once, more than once or not at all
Fig. 6.1 shows a ray of light inside a semi-circular glass block
The angle of incidence at the straight surface is **less** than the critical angle for the glass
On Fig. 6.1, continue the path of the ray
On Fig. 6.2, continue the path of the ray
State the term used to describe what happens to the light when it strikes the straight surface in Fig. 6.2
Fig. 6.2 shows another ray of light inside a semi-circular glass block
The angle of incidence at the straight surface is **greater** than the critical angle for the glass
A wave on the surface of water approaches a barrier. There is a small gap in the barrier, as shown in Fig. 6.3
On Fig. 6.3, draw **three** wavefronts that have passed through the gap
Sound from the radio makes an air particle at X vibrate
On Fig. 7.1 draw two arrows on point X to show the directions of vibration of the air particle
Which of these terms correctly describes the sound wave?
Tick one box
Suggest a value for the frequency of the sound that the man can hear. State the unit
frequency = .........
Explain why the man cannot hear ultrasound
Fig. 7.1 shows a man listening to a radio
Use the graph to calculate the speed of ultrasound in sea-water
A scientist measures the depth of the sea by using ultrasound. She sends a pulse of ultrasound from the ship to the seabed. It reflects from the seabed as shown in Fig. 7.3
The time taken between sending a pulse and receiving the echo is 0.60 s. Use the graph to determine the depth of the sea
Fig. 7.2 shows a distance-time graph for ultrasound travelling in sea-water
Describe how to use this apparatus to identify the magnetic field pattern of the bar magnet
Fig. 8.2 shows a bar magnet
Fig. 8.1 shows a plotting compass and a bar magnet. The plotting compass consists of a small magnet in the shape of an arrow. The arrow can rotate freely on a pivot
On Fig. 9.1, label the thermistor
The student measures the potential difference (p.d.) across the thermistor
On Fig. 9.1, draw a voltmeter symbol, correctly connected, to measure this potential difference
The potential difference across the thermistor is 6.0 V
Calculate the resistance of the thermistor when its temperature is \(40^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
resistance = .........\(\Omega\)
Describe and explain what happens to the current in the thermistor as the temperature of the thermistor rises
Suggest a value for the current in the thermistor at \(80^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
The student varies the temperature of the thermistor and measures the current in it
Some of the results are shown in the table
At a different temperature, the resistance of the thermistor is \(300\Omega\) and the resistance of the variable resistor is \(400\Omega\)
Calculate the value of their combined resistance
combined resistance = .........\(\Omega\)
A student investigates how the resistance of a thermistor changes with temperature
Fig. 9.1 shows part of the circuit the student uses
The meter measures the size and direction of the induced electromotive force (e.m.f.). On Fig. 10.2, draw the position of the pointer on the meter at each stage
One has been done for you
Describe how the student could increase the size of the induced electromotive force (e.m.f.)
A student investigates electromagnetic induction
Fig. 10.1 shows the arrangement she uses
When the student holds the wire stationary, as shown in Fig. 10.1, the reading on the meter is zero
She moves the wire down between the poles of the magnet. Then she holds it stationary and then moves it up
A transformer is used near a power station
There are 60 turns on the input coil and 660 turns on the output coil
The input voltage is 25 000 V
Calculate the output voltage
output voltage = .........V
State two advantages of high-voltage transmission of electrical energy
State the number of protons in a nucleus of polonium-210 .......................................
State the number of neutrons in a nucleus of polonium-210 .......................................
State the number of electrons in a neutral atom of polonium-210 ................................
Polonium-210 is radioactive. When polonium-210 decays it emits alpha radiation
Name two other types of radiation emitted when radioactive elements decay
Polonium-210 has a half-life of 138 days
A sample of polonium-210 has a mass of \(0.4\mathrm{g}\)
Calculate the time for the sample to decay until only \(0.1\mathrm{g}\) of polonium-210 remains
time = .........days
A nucleus of polonium-210 can be represented as \(^{210}_{84}\mathrm{Po}\)
Explain why radioactive sources can be dangerous
Describe how to reduce the risks when working with radioactive sources
A scientist needs to reduce the risks when working with radioactive sources
